shropshire wedding photographer

19th May 2012

I had the pleasure of photographing John & Aimee’s Wedding day on the 19th May 2012 at St John’s The Baptist church, Ditton Priors. It was an extra special wedding as I grew up with John & Aimee so had to pull out all the stops! The weather started out slightly iffy but the atmosphere of all the local well wishers soon dismissed that , I don’t think anyone even noticed. Everyone looked amazing on the day from the flowers, and all the little extras.

copyright images to Meg Hawkins 2012

Lots of friendly faces, the question that is asked of me at most of my weddings to you enjoy photographing weddings?

‘well OF COURSE!’

I answer every time how often do you get to go somewhere when everyone is full of light and happiness’

John & Aimee’s wedding was full of warmth and love and was a beautiful day filled with memories set for a lifetime of stories to be told

Just for a cheeky pit stop at there local pub ‘the three horse shoes’ Wheathill.

For a quick pint before we ventured of to the reception at ‘Cadmore Lodge Hotel’ in Tenbury.

It was a perfect Shropshire Wedding, John told me that he wanted to keep everything local and he managed it perfectly, Aimee all your hard work paid off and the photos prove what a stunning emotional happy day it was.

I wanted to do something different in my studio, initial thoughts where graffiti, and they are still in mind,

but I decided that pop art style may be a little different so I set to work on finding fashion images that could be simplified,

and items that go with the industry i.e lipstick. I wanted to put as much bright colour in and incorporate pattern too. To achieve a vibrant eye catching style

One of my favourite artists of today is Banksy so I added a small feature along his style, a little girl silhouette stencil with the red balloon.

The mural is yet to be finished and doubt it ever will be as I am going to then keep adding to it with graffiti I think and extra multi media add on’s J

‘It’s fun, bright and cheerful just what we all need on these dull gloomy days we’ve been having.’

I photographed throughout Meg Hawkins Photography Studio Mural 2012

Keep a look out for the extras when added…

The Romance of the dress

A twist on the old Romantic meets the darkness of the unknown supernatural.

I have asked Thea our model for the day to give us her interpretation on her day…

“Creation started early one spring morning, turning up at Meg Hawkins Photography Studio Burwarton, in nothing but my dressing gown

As i stared into the mirror with blurry eyes i watched Liz Bell Hair & Makeup work her magic, back combing and quaffing, crimping and twisting ; my blank canvas of a face was transformed into a sultry temptress with eyes dark eyes full of secrets!!

There she was looking back at me, a reflection I’d never seen before.”

Off we went truck packed with supplies and ‘ the dress’ . location Brown Clee, Burwarton Estate.

Arrived at location chosen by Meg Hawkins.

Criteria: Spooky Trees!

I was stripped to my underwear ( at this point I feel I should share the temperature 4degrees!!! ) squeezed into what i can only describe as an amazing creation, deep tones of mulberry’s, merging into layers of fantastic ebony chiffon edged with lace designed by Hayley J Shrewsbury Bridal couture., as I breathed in one final time my look was complete! Well until coral pointed out my jewellery was missing, swarovski crystals seemed the perfect choice, Otazu earrings, bracelet and necklace were all carefully adorned, instantly picking up the struggling sunshine through the threatening clouds, and the crowning glory a tiara loaded with more Swarovski bling, also from the fabulous Hayley J, Shrewsbury.

Shoes were slipped onto my feet Hard hearted Harlet seemed the perfect choice to achieve a few extra inches, but also difficult to cross country run in when I heard Meg Hawkins shout on 3 RUN!

And thus the shot was created

Thank you to all involved Liz Bell Make up Meg Hawkins Creative director and Photographer, Coral Hawkins Assistant who made this happen

Thea xx

It was such a great day although Cold we all shivered through and the sun broke through

More to come soon…..

events photography

Being an Events photographer is not just about taking a pretty picture. It’s about creating a story for your client of the day they have plumbed there heart and sole into creating.

My Job is to capture as much as I can out of it from all the little details to the obvious points in front of you .

When all the hard work comes together…

The Old Vicarage Adventure Centre open Day 13th May 2012

What an amazing inspiring day out, on arrival we were welcomed by staff from the centre, the event was very well organized, we were directed to the car park then on to the marquee tent to register. With lots of activities going on it was a question of where to start, the day was set out for children and adults alike.

All the activities where supervised by a ovac member of staff.

First port of call, the Climbing wall, seemed a very popular event, from small children as young as 1-2 yrs old attempted the big grey pillar. From a spectator point of view it looked easy but then watching them pulling there little selves up this wall was quite an achievement. And the get to the top WOW Brilliant!

Next we popped over the jousting great bit of fun for everyone who doesn’t like knocking someone of their stand? !

The Old Vicarage gave a presentation, on what courses they have offer, summer Camps etc. Events for children and adults.

We went and watched a play boat demo on the lake which was weird and wonderful at the same time.

Laser Tag was great fun for the kids it was hard to get any of our team back in from the ‘field!’

Caving now that was an experience, the nerve and anticipation for everyone who went down the dark whole was quite funny to watch. They scrambled on thier hands and knees through the clay tunnels and eventually came out the other side very funny but again many achieved something new.

One of the most up to date events was Slacklining, totally fascinating sport

It’s a practice in balance that typically uses 1 inch nylon webbing tensioned between two anchor points. Slacklining is distinct from tightrope walking that the line is not held rigidly taut (although it is still under some tension); it is instead dynamic, stretching and bouncing like a long and narrow trampoline.

The balance and control the demo staff used was amazing.

staff of Tri-Slacklining Ltd. Live the Adventure Ltd offer slacklining as an activity at the Old Vicarage Adventure Centre following coaching and training from Tri-Slacklining.

There was Archery, mountain boarding Kayak displays and Leap of Faith.

We didn’t manage to get round them all but Pony riding seemed one of the most popular, for children that don’t get the chance to ever experience small thing that others take for granted for this proved to be excellent for them.

The younger members of staff where very professional with leading the pony’s round and had full control all the time. All the staff worked so hard and it proved to be an event not to be missed .

‘Live The Adventure’ is the most perfect description for the ‘The Old Vicarage Centre.’

Live the Adventure Ltd, ovac@livetheadventure.co, 01746 718 436 www.livetheadventure.co

Natural Wedding photography

WOW digital! It’s fantastic for modern wedding day photography, its limits are vast and exciting, there is no more 24 shots films and ‘pot luck’ if you got everyone or not, then waiting for your photos to come through in the post. It’s just brilliant we are able to view as we go along if it didn’t work well just take another one in a professional way of course!

Some people may say that I am ‘click’ happy well… they’d be right I love it ! Natural photography, capturing someone unaware of you being there, and ‘snap!’ moment of no pressure of having your photo taken and show a reflection of the real you.

I find a mass majority of guests at a wedding don’t really like having there photo taken and when they have it done they feel very stiff and mostly have a fake smile attached, this is why natural unobtrusive shots work best in my opinion. Weddings are such a happy event in the in the sense of tears of happiness and pure fulfilment, the moments when a bride walks down the stairs and the father sees his little girl looking stunning, or that quick glimpse down the isle from the groom just a sneak peek to see what his beautiful bride to be look like, the nervous small giggle when saying your vows, and the kiss! well moments like you don’t forget and I am there to catch them. The fact is I am there to capture these moments as you will remember them having them in a photograph give your friends and family the joy of sharing it too.

Guests… these are brilliant shots too, you have spent your time organising your wedding right through to the very last details and you have spent the time too thinking who’s going to come? who’s going to sit next to who? ‘Will uncle Kev want to be at next to great auntie Rita?’ Well they all sort it out in the end. It’s brilliant seeing relatives who haven’t seen each other for many years join up again with a fantastic embrace of a huge hug! the children’s faces when some one they’ve never met get a hug of a relative and they say “haven’t you grown’ well these are the guests way of making your story book up, the natural joy of life brought together from just the delight of love.

I guess what I am trying to say is the most favoured shots are caught in the ‘moment’ through a lens is just perfect! .

Nothing is better than a friendly smile on one of your most important days of your life. What do you want most on your big day ? Fun, happiness memories laughter love… Meg strives to capture all these and more to create a story book for you to cherish for a life time of ‘tales to BE told.’

She handles your crowed with humour and patience creating a calm atmosphere for you and you guests, which makes her approachable. She works efficiently when taking your posed shots so not to have you and your guests hanging around for too long, this then leaves time for those all important natural, individual discrete ‘fly on the wall’ shots.

Hopefully your wedding reflects who you are as a couple and shines with your personality including your most favourite people in the world to give you the best day to remember for ever.

Meg’s approach to her photogrpahy implores Natural, stylish and contemporary imagery which she hopes reflects in her work.

Top Tips in Getting the Right Wedding Photographer for Your

There are quite a few variations in the style of wedding photography. The style of wedding photography depends on the type of photographer your wedding photographer is. Is he someone who visualizes through his camera in the traditional way or someone who does creative shots. There is a growing movement towards an unobtrusive method of catching moments of the wedding day which is more natural in its approach. It captures the wedding day as it unfolds. There will be less of the usual gathering of the couple and guests to pose for photographs. The photographer is almost invisible to the family and friends and simply capture the moments as they happen.

This style of wedding photography creates a narrative and more natural style, each photograph will help tell a comprehensive story of your wedding day. It starts with how the bride prepares for her special day, and ends with the party that comes after. The whole idea of documentary wedding photography is to capture moments in a chronological order as it happens during your wedding day. The photographer keeps an eye on everything that happens and try to capture the defining moments of the wedding. The duty of the wedding photographer is to produce photographs that will remain special for both the groom and the bride as they will recreate their wedding day through pictures.

What is exceptional with this style of wedding photography, is that the day can commence without any disturbance usually caused by people having to pose for pictures. The groom and bride can focus on what really matters on their wedding day which is to show their love for each other.

This style of natural wedding photography creates a story which will unfold as the day progresses. All the pictures will help recreate the wedding day as it happened and hopefully will tell a good story. Remember your wedding is a special day. Details such as how the food tasted, how the cake looked, how the guests enjoyed the party pale in comparison to how the wedding photographs will turn out, not only should it be good but exceptional. After all once the day is over, it is the photographs that will remind you how special was your wedding day.

When you are ready to decide on who will be your wedding photographer, here are some tips that will help you decide who to hire as your wedding photographer. You should get someone who is the best in his craft, someone who can deliver the best photographs and also someone who can offer different wedding photography packages. It is also important to hire someone who is adept in handling the technicalities behind good wedding photography. If for example you are living in a place where there is a grand amount of natural light, make sure you hire a photographer who knows how to manage different lighting conditions.

Ask for samples of the photographer's work. Remember the saying "A picture is worth a thousand words", the photographer's work will speak for itself. By their work you can judge if he is the right <a target="_new" rel="follow" href="]natural wedding photographer[/url] for you. Ask for honest feedback from couples who have worked with this photographer. Lastly ask about the wedding packages your wedding photographer offers. In the end you may want to get all the photos taken. There may be photos that you would feel a personal connection to regardless what the wedding photographer may think about it. Remember your wedding day is personal and sometimes no matter how some photos may lack in artistic value in the eyes of the wedding photographer they may be the very photographs that will remind you how special your wedding day was and without them will not complete your wedding story.

Lou & Rob Glastonbury Wedding

‘Our eyes met across the crowded field, our hearts stopped and from that moment we were inseparable…. Well that’s how I like to think that Rob and I met at Glastonbury 2004, but it couldn’t be further from the truth. He staggered into our campsite with a crate of Carlsberg over his head shouting “milky milky” at the top of his voice and proceeded to put up his tent. Inside out. Maybe not the most auspicious of starts…

At the Soulmates speed dating tent the next day it seemed that the stars were still plotting against us. Rob was matched up with nobody and I was matched up with… his best friend. After deciding that Dave and I had nothing more in common than our mutual love of Morrissey I ditched him and hoped that Rob was still inside on his lonesome. (Dave wasn’t too bitter; he did end up as our Best Man.)

As luck would have it Rob was still alone and from then on we were pretty much inseparable (apart from my day long stint at the front of the Pyramid Stage waiting for Morrissey.) I even said that if Rob and I did get together it wouldn’t just be for a short fling, but even I didn’t expect us to be walking up the aisle seven years later.

As we met at Glastonbury it seemed fitting to incorporate as many festival elements as we could into our day. We both wanted a traditional church wedding so it was at our reception that our ideas really came to life (although I did walk down the aisle in a pair of custom made Converse…)! 130m of homemade bunting; 120 VIP lanyards; 150 cotton shopping bags (made by the same company that make the Glastonbury bags); 20 hand painted Wellington boot centre pieces (complete with Glastonbury stage names) and 90 mini campervans later and we’d created the festival atmosphere we were after.

We rocked up to our reception at The Bear Inn and Hotel in the Peak District in a beautifully restored 1968 split screen VW campervan. Half way to the reception we also stopped off for an amazing private photo-shoot with our photographer Meg Hawkins where we got some of the most special pictures of our day. Throw in an extra shoot for myself and my bridesmaids bedecked in wellies and we couldn’t have asked for more. Our cake, made by Lady Jayne’s Cakes was a tower of cupcakes that included a bespoke Glastonboozy cider flavour that went down a treat with our guests. So much so that Rob and I didn’t get any! Our band (The Flange) covered songs from our favourite bands and artists and the dance floor resembled the front of the Pyramid Stage for the entire night.

The day totally exceeded our expectations. We have never laughed and smiled so much and the same could be said for all our guests too. At Glastonbury 2004 a band I’d never heard of (and haven’t heard of since) called the Ralph Myerz and the Jack Herren Band told us to “Put your hands in the air and something special happens!” On 30th July 2011 we did put our hands in the air. And something special truly happened. ‘

And that’s that pure Joy!

Meg

<p style="text-align: center;]We rocked up to our reception at The Bear Inn and Hotel in the Peak District in a beautifully restored 1968 split screen VW campervan. Half way to the reception we also stopped off for an amazing private photo-shoot with our photographer Meg Hawkins where we got some of the most special pictures of our day. Throw in an extra shoot for myself and my bridesmaids bedecked in wellies and we couldn’t have asked for more. Our cake, made by Lady Jayne’s Cakes was a tower of cupcakes that included a bespoke Glastonboozy cider flavour that went down a treat with our guests. So much so that Rob and I didn’t get any! Our band (The Flange) covered songs from our favourite bands and artists and the dance floor resembled the front of the Pyramid Stage for the entire night.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;]The day totally exceeded our expectations.  We have never laughed and smiled so much and the same could be said for all our guests too. At Glastonbury 2004 a band I’d never heard of (and haven’t heard of since) called the Ralph Myerz and the Jack Herren Band told us to “Put your hands in the air and something special happens!” On 30<sup>th</sup> July 2011 we did put our hands in the air. And something special truly happened. ‘</p>
<p style="text-align: center;]And that’s that pure Joy!</p>
